channel.title: Comments on: Raspberry Pi powered heating controller (Part 4)

item.title: By: Will Cooke
item.dc:creator: Will Cooke
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2014/02/04/raspberry-pi-powered-heating-controller-part-4/#comment-60">Les</a>.
Hi Les,
Yes! I have integrated it with Alexa - and it was pretty easy actually. I needed a proxy on my home network that was exposed to the Internet so that Alexa can make REST calls to the heating controller.
I'm at the point now where I don't even have the heating on a timer anymore - I just command Alexa to switch it on and off as I need it. The hot water is still on a timer though.
I've also hooked it up to Apple Homekit so that I can switch the heating on when I'm away from home. This is useful when we're out for the day and can come home to a nice warm house.
I've posted a bit about Alexa integrations on here.

item.title: By: Will Cooke
item.dc:creator: Will Cooke
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2014/02/04/raspberry-pi-powered-heating-controller-part-4/#comment-58">James Tulloch</a>.
The outside temperature ones are easy. I went up in to the loft and poked a waterproof sensor out of the bottom of the roof, where the guttering would be. For the tank sensors; my tank has a solid foam jacket, so I used a pencil to "drill" a whole through it until I got to the tank itself, then I used a bit of thermal compound that you use to attach heatsinks to CPUs, squirted in in to the bottom of the hole and pushed a temp. sensor in to it. It's a hack, but it works fine!
